We investigate the changes when applying a scaling transformation \\( f(x) = kx(t) \\), where \\( k \\) is a constant scalar.

If an additional transformation \\( g(x) = m*x(T-t) \\) (time reversal and scaling by \\( m \\)) is applied as an intervention at a time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint \\( z(T) \\) solely depend on the original scaling factor \\( k \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with transformation \\( g(x) \\) modifies the input in a fundamentally new way by not only scaling but also reversing the time profile of the input. This changes the convolution dynamics, making the final output at time \\( T \\) dependent on both the original scale \\( k \\) and the new scale and modality \\( m \\).
